DT Article
TI Conidames, a new oriental genus of Sycophaginae (Hymenoptera, Agaonidae)
   associated with Ficus section Conosycea (Moraceae).
AU Farache, Fernando Henrique Antoniolli (fhafarache@gmail.com) 
   Rasplus, Jean-Yves
SO ZooKeys
VL 539
PS 119-145
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The sycophagines are strictly associated with two subgenera of Fit to L.
   (Moraceae), namely,Slycomo77/S and Urostignza. They mostly oviposit
   through the fig wall and lay their eggs within the fig flowers, being
   either gall-makers or parasitoids of other fig wasps. In this
   contribution, a new genus of Sycophaginae, Conidarnes Earache & Rasplus,
   gen. n., is described with seven new species: Conidarnes achterbergi
   Earache & Rasplus, sp. n.; Conidarwes beryl' Farache & Rasplus, sp. n.;
   Conidarnes laevis Earache & Rasplus, sp. n.; Conidames santineloi
   Earache & Rasplus, sp. n.; Conidarnes subtectae Earache & Rasplus, sp.
   n.; Conidarnes sidcata Farache & Rasplus, sp. n.; and Conidarnes
   sumatranae Farache & Rasplus, sp. n. Illustrations, morphological
   diagnoses, dichotomous keys and multi-entry online keys to species are
   provided. Conidarnes species strictly occur in the oriental region, and
   their distribution does not oVerlap with the distribution of the two
   other genera belonging to the same clade. Due to their relative rarity,
   we encourage extensive sampling of Conosycea figs to improve our
   knowledge of the genus.
C1 Farache, Fernando Henrique Antoniolli; Univ Sao Paulo, FFCLRP, Ribeirao
   Preto, SP, BR-14049, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fhafarache@gmail.com
RI Rasplus, Jean-Yves/O-2873-2017; Farache, Fernando Henrique/D-6049-2015

   mutualistic species] [Indonesia /  / New species; plant mutual]. 
   Conidarnes laevis [Mutualism / Ficus kerkhoveni (Plant) / New
   mutualistic species] [Indonesia /  / New species; plant mutual]. 
   Conidarnes santineloi [Mutualism / Ficus pallescens (Plant) / New
   mutualistic species] [Brunei /  / New species; plant mutual].

   mutualistic species] [Brunei /  / New species; plant mutual].

   Chalcidoidea, Agaonidae
OR Conidarnes (Agaonidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Sycophaginae, Type
   species Conidarnes santineloi, p. 121; Key to species, P. 122]. 
   Conidarnes achterbergi (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 123]. 
   Conidarnes bergi (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, type horizon not
   given, Mutualistic with Ficus involucrata (Plant), p. 125]. 
   Conidarnes laevis (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, Mutualistic with
   Ficus kerkhoveni (Plant), p. 128]. 
   Conidarnes santineloi (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Brunei, Mutualistic with
   Ficus pallescens (Plant), p. 131]. 
   Conidarnes subtectae (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Brunei, Mutualistic with

   Conidarnes sulcata (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, Mutualistic with Ficus
   altissima (Plant), p. 134]. 
   Conidarnes sumatranae (Agaonidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, Mutualistic with
   Ficus sumatrana (Plant), p. 138].

DT Article
TI Description of Pella tianmuensis sp n. from eastern China (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae, Aleocharinae).
AU Yan, Zhu-Qi
   Li, Li-Zhen (lizhenli@shnu.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 539
PS 147-150
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pella tianmuensis sp. n., a inyrinecophile associated with Lasius
   (Dendrolasius) spathepus Wheeler, 1910 in West Tianmushan Natural
   Reserve, Zhejiang, is described, illustrated and distinguished from its
   congeners.
C1 Li, Li-Zhen; Shanghai Normal Univ, Coll Life & Environm Sci, 100 Guilin
   Rd, Shanghai, 200234, China, China.

   (Hymenoptera) / New associate species] [Zhejiang /  / New species;
   hymenopteran associate].

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Muricea Lamouroux, 1821 (Anthozoa, Octocorallia)
   in the eastern Pacific. Part I: Eumuricea Verrill, 1869 revisited.
AU Breedy, Odalisca (odaliscab@gmail.com) 
   Guzman, Hector M.
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 1-32
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Muricea is an amphi-American genus. Verrill proposed dividing the
   species from the Pacific Ocean into three genera and established the
   genus Eumuricea for five eastern Pacific species with tubular calyces.
   Eumuricea is basically characterized by colonies with elongate,
   cylindrical calyces with truncate margins and star-like opercula, and
   the occurrence of unilateral spinous spindles. According to these
   characteristics, Eumuricea does not show enough difference from Muricea
   to be treated as a separate genus. Original type material of Eumuricea
   was morphologically analysed and illustrated using optical and scanning
   electron microscopy. We conclude that the eastern Pacific species should
   be placed in the genus Muricea and form a group characterised by tubular
   calyces that comprises four species at present, M. acervata, M. hispida,
   M. squarrosa, and M. tubigera and a dubious species M. horrida.
   Lectotypes were designated for M. squarrosa and M. hispida to establish
   their taxonomic status. The genus Eumuricea has also been misunderstood
   by former authors who erroneously assigned species to it. For these
   species we propose new combinations: Swiftia pusilla, Astrogorgia
   splendens and A. ramosa.
C1 Breedy, Odalisca; Univ Costa Rica, Ctr Invest Ciencias Mar & Limnol, POB
   11501-2060, San Jose, Costa Rica, Costa Rica.
EM odaliscab@gmail.com
RI Breedy, Odalisca/A-9380-2011
OI Guzman, Hector M./0000-0001-9928-8523
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Diagnosis; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Marine zones
DE Muricea [Pacific Ocean / East / Taxonomic revision]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Octocorallia
OR Astrogorgia ramosa - (Thomson & Simpson 1909) (Octocorallia): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Eumuricea, p. 26]. 
   Astrogorgia splendens - (Thomson & Simpson 1909) (Octocorallia): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Eumuricea, p. 24]. 
   Eumuricea - Verrill 1869 (Octocorallia): [Junior synonym, Of Muricea
   Lamouroux 1821, p. 1]. 
   Eumuricea pusilla - Nutting 1909 (Octocorallia): [Referred to, Swiftia,
   p. 22]. 
   Eumuricea ramosa - Thomson & Simpson 1909 (Octocorallia): [Referred to,
   Astrogorgia, p. 26]. 
   Eumuricea splendens - Thomson & Simpson 1909 (Octocorallia): [Referred
   to, Astrogorgia, p. 24]. 
   Muricea - Lamouroux 1821 (Octocorallia): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 15; Senior synonym, Of Eumuricea Verrill 1869, p.
   1]. 
   Muricea hispida - Verrill 1866 (Octocorallia): [Lectotype designated, P.
   10]. 
   Muricea horrida - Moebius 1861 (Octocorallia): [Status, P. 15]. 
   Muricea squarrosa - Verrill 1869 (Octocorallia): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 15]. 
   Plexauridae - Gray 1859 (Octocorallia): [Key to genera, Modified key, p.
   6]. 
   Swiftia pusilla - (Nutting 1909) (Octocorallia): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Eumuricea, p. 22].

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of Galumnoidea (Acari, Oribatida) of Cuba.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Tolstikov, Andrei V.
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 65-78
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB An annotated checklist of identified oribatid mites of the superfamily
   Galumnoidea collected from Cuba, including ten species from four genera
   and two families, is provided. Galumna flabellifera Hammer, 1958,
   Pergalumna bifissurata Hammer, 1972, P. bryani (Jacot, 1934), P.
   decorata Balogh & Mahunka, 1977 and Galumnopsis secunda Sellnick, 1923
   are recorded for the first time in the Cuban fauna. A new species of
   Pergalumna, P. cubaensis sp. n., is described; it is morphologically
   similar to P. decorata Balogh & Mahunka, 1977, but differs from the
   latter by the larger body size, heavily granulated prodorsum and
   well-developed interlamellar setae. The adult of Allogalumna cubana
   Balogh & Mahunka, 1979 is redescribed.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
RI Tolstikov, Andrey/B-2119-2013
OI Tolstikov, Andrey/0000-0002-8537-038X
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Publications; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West
   Indies
DE Galumna flabellifera; Galumnopsis secunda; Pergalumna bifissurata;
   Pergalumna bryani; Pergalumna decorata [Cuba /  / New record]. 
   Galumnoidea [Checklists / Annotated checklist / ] [Cuba /  / ]. 
   Pergalumna cubaensis [Cuba /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Allogalumna cubana - Balogh & Mahunka 1979 (Acari): [Redescription,
   Adult, p. 71]. 
   Galumna flabellifera (Acari): [New record]. 
   Galumnoidea (Acari). 
   Galumnopsis secunda (Acari): [New record]. 
   Pergalumna bifissurata (Acari): [New record]. 
   Pergalumna bryani (Acari): [New record]. 
   Pergalumna cubaensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 66]. 
   Pergalumna decorata (Acari): [New record].

DT Article
TI A new highly specialized cave harvestman from Brazil and the first blind
   species of the genus: Iandumoema smeagol sp. n. (Arachnida, Opiliones,
   Gonyleptidae).
AU Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo (ricrocha@usp.br) 
   da Fonseca-Ferreira, Rafael
   Bichuette, Maria Elina
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 79-95
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of troglobitic harvestman, landumoema smeagol sp. n., is
   described from Toca do Geraldo, Monjolos municipality, Minas Gerais
   state, Brazil. Iandumoema smeagol sp. n. is distinguished from the other
   two species of the genus by four exclusive characteristics - dorsal
   scutum areas with conspicuous tubercles, enlarged retrolateral spiniform
   tubercle on the distal third of femur IV, eyes absent and the penial
   ventral process slender and of approximately the same length of the
   stylus. The species is the most highly modified in the genus and its
   distribution is restricted only to caves in that particular area of
   Minas Gerais state. The type locality is not inside a legally protected
   area, and there are anthropogenic impacts in its surroundings.
   Therefore, Iandumoema smeagol sp. n. is vulnerable and it must be
   considered in future conservation projects.
C1 Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo; Univ Sao Paulo, Inst Biociencias, Rua
   Matao,Travessa 14,321, Sao Paulo, SP, BR-05508090 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ricrocha@usp.br
RI Bichuette, Maria Elina/C-5262-2013; Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo/J-6774-2012
OI Bichuette, Maria Elina/0000-0002-9515-4832; Pinto-da-Rocha,
   Ricardo/0000-0002-3959-2205; da Fonseca Ferreira,
   Rafael/0000-0002-9912-6302
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Iandumoema smeagol (Opiliones): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 83].

TI A new species of Pseudomegischus van Achterberg from China, with a key
   to the species (Hymenoptera, Stephanidae).
AU Tan, Jiang-Li (tanjl@nwu.edu.cn) 
   Fan, Xu-Lei
   van Achterberg, Cornelis
   Li, Tao
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 103-110
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Pseudomegischus van Achterberg, 2002, is newly reported from
   China. A new species, P. notiochinensis sp. n., is described and
   illustrated from southern China. A key to the species of Pseudomegischus
   is included.

DT Article
TI Revision of the West Indian Wattius Kaszab (Tenebrionidae, Toxicini,
   Eudysantina) with lectotype designations for Pascoe's South American
   species.
AU Smith, Aaron D. (Aaron.Smith@nau.edu) 
   Sanchez, Lucio A.
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 111-130
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Wattius species occurring in the West Indies are revised for the
   first time. Wattius cucullatus (Pascoe), previously reported from Cuba,
   is diagnosed and restricted to Brazil. Wattius asperulus (Pascoe),
   currently a synonym of W. cucullatus, from Colombia is diagnosed and
   resurrected. All species found in the West Indies are endemic to the
   islands and form a single informal species-group. Three species are
   described: Wattius andersoni sp. n. from Cuba, Wattius emmabaconae sp.
   n. from Hispaniola (Dominican Republic), and Wattius viatorus sp. n.
   from Cuba and the Bahamas, and lectotypes are designated for Calymmus
   cucullatus Pascoe and Calymmus asperulus Pascoe. A key to the West
   Indian species is provided.
C1 Smith, Aaron D.; No Arizona Univ, Dept Biol Sci, POB 5640, Flagstaff,
   AZ, 86011, USA, USA.
EM Aaron.Smith@nau.edu
OI Smith, Aaron/0000-0002-1286-950X
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies
DE Wattius [West Indies /  / Key to species] [ /  / Taxonomc revision]. 
   Wattius andersoni [Cuba /  / New species]. 
   Wattius emmabaconae [Dominican Republic /  / New species]. 
   Wattius viatorus [Bahamas /  / New species] [Cuba /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Calymmus asperulus - Pascoe 1871 (Tenebrionidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 117]. 
   Calymmus cucullatus - Pascoe 1871 (Tenebrionidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 115]. 
   Wattius - Kaszab 1982 (Tenebrionidae): [Key to species, West Indies, P.
   114]. 
   Wattius andersoni (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 118]. 
   Wattius asperulus - (Pascoe 1871) (Tenebrionidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Wattius cucullatus (Pascoe 1871), p. 117]. 
   Wattius cucullatus - (Pascoe 1871) (Tenebrionidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Wattius asperulus (Pascoe 1871), p. 117]. 
   Wattius emmabaconae (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P.
   121]. 
   Wattius viatorus (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 125].

DT Article
TI Three new species of Hagnagora Druce, 1885 (Lepidoptera, Geometridae,
   Larentiinae) from Ecuador and Costa Rica and a concise revision of the
   genus.
AU Brehm, Gunnar (gunnar.brehm@uni-jena.de) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 537
PS 131-156
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three new Hagnagora Druce species (Geometridae, Larentiinae) are
   described: Hagnagora richardi Brehm, sp. n. from Ecuador, H. hedwigae
   Brehm, sp. n. from Ecuador, and H. mirandahenrichae Brehm, sp. n. from
   Costa Rica. A checklist of taxa assigned to Hagnagora is provided.
   Hagnagora is provisionally divided into six clades: the anicata clade (6
   species), the buckleyi clade (3 species), the croceitincta clade (3
   species), the ephestris clade (3 species), the mortipax clade (4
   species) and H. subrosea (1 species). Two taxa are revived from
   synonymy: H. catagrammina Druce, stat. rev. and H. luteoradiata
   Thierry-Mieg, stat. rev. Two taxa are reinstated from subspecies to
   species level: H. acothysta Schaus, stat. rev. and H. jamaicensis
   Schaus, stat. rev. Four taxa are provisionally removed from Hagnagora:
   "Hagnagora" ignipennis, "Hagnagora" mesenata, "Hagnagora" vittata, and
   "Hagnagora" ceraria. After these changes, the genus Hagnagora now
   comprises 20 valid species.
C1 Brehm, Gunnar; Inst Spezielle Zool & Evolut Biol Phylet Museum, Vor dem
   Neutor 1, Jena, D-07743, Germany, Germany.
EM gunnar.brehm@uni-jena.de
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central
   America; South America
DE Hagnagora [Checklists / Distributional & taxonomic checklist / ]. 
   Hagnagora hedwigae; Hagnagora richardi [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
   Hagnagora mirandahenrichae [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

   Hagnagora acothysta - Schaus 1901 (Geometridae): [Raised from, Hagnagora
   mortipax acothysta, p. 149]. 
   Hagnagora buckleyi - Druce 1885 (Geometridae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Hagnagora catagrammina Druce 1885, p. 140]. 
   Hagnagora catagrammina - Druce 1885 (Geometridae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Hagnagora buckleyi Druce 1885, p. 140]. 
   Hagnagora ephestris - (Felder & Rogenhofer 1875) (Geometridae): [Removal
   from synonymy, Hagnagora luteoradiata (Thierry-Mieg 1892), p. 152]. 
   Hagnagora hedwigae (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 144]. 
   Hagnagora jamaicensis - Schaus 1901 (Geometridae): [Raised from,
   Hagnagora mortipax jamaicensis, p. 148]. 
   Hagnagora luteoradiata - (Thierry-Mieg 1892) (Geometridae): [Removal
   from synonymy, With Hagnagora ephestris (Felder & Rogenhofer 1875), p.
   152]. 
   Hagnagora mirandahenrichae (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, P. 147]. 
   Hagnagora mortipax acothysta - Schaus 1901 (Geometridae): [Raised to,
   Hagnagora acothysta, p. 149]. 
   Hagnagora mortipax jamaicensis - Schaus 1901 (Geometridae): [Raised to,
   Hagnagora jamaicensis, p. 148]. 
   Hagnagora richardi (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 143].

DT Article
TI The genus Pterostichus in China II: the subgenus Circinatus Sciaky, a
   species revision and phylogeny (Carabidae, Pterostichini).
AU Shi, Hongliang
   Liang, Hongbin (lianghb@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 536
PS 1-92
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB All of the known species of the Chinese endemic subgenus Pterostichus
   (Circinatus) are revised, keyed, and illustrated. Eleven new species and
   one new subspecies are described: P. adelphus sp. n. (Sichuan: Meigu,
   N28.66[degree], E103.06[degree]); P. ailaoicus sp. n. (Yunnan: Xinping,
   N23.94[degree], E101.50[degree]); P. camelus sp. n. (Sichuan: Mianning,
   N28.97[degree], E102.16[degree]); P. dimorphus sp. n. (Yunnan: Dayao,
   N26.08[degree], E101.03[degree]); P. maitreya sp. n. (Guizhou:
   Fanjingshan, N27.90[degree], E108.70[degree]); P. miao sp. n. (Guangxi:
   Maoershan, N25.87[degree], E110.41[degree]); P. tumulus sp. n. (Guizhou:
   Fanjingshan, N27.90[degree], E108.70[degree]); P. wangjiani sp. n.
   (Yunnan: Dongchuan, N26.08[degree], E102.87[degree]); P. yan sp. n.
   (Hubei: Shennongjia, N31.47[degree], E110.39[degree]); P. yuxiaodongi
   sp. n. (Sichuan: Wolong, N30.99[degree], E103.15[degree]); P. zhygealu
   sp. n. (Sichuan: Meigu, N28.67[degree], E103.05[degree]); and P.
   cavazzutianus mianningensis subsp. n. (Sichuan: Mianning,
   N28.97[degree], E102.16[degree]). P. cavazzutianus is proposed as a
   replacement name for P. cavazuttii Allegro and Sciaky 2010, preoccupied
   by P. (Sinosteropus) barbarae cavazuttii Sciaky and Facchini 2003. A
   lectotype is designated for P. baenningeri Jedlicka 1931. Two species,
   P. schuelkei Sciaky & Wrase and P. wenxianensis Allegro & Sciaky, are
   moved from the subgenus Circinatus to Morphohaptoderus. An
   infra-subgeneric taxonomy is proposed for the subgenus Circinatus with
   four species groups. The male endophallus characters for most species of
   Circinatus were well studied, with three types of endophallus defined. A
   phylogenetic analysis based on adult morphological characters confirmed
   the infra-subgeneric classification and clarified some of the
   relationships among species. Two main lineages within Circinatus were
   identified from the phylogenetic analyses. Three of the four species
   groups were monophyletic, whereas the fourth group was paraphyletic.
C1 Liang, Hongbin; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Beijing, 100101, China,
   China.
EM lianghb@ioz.ac.cn
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970

   Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI Annotated check list of the Pyraloidea (Lepidoptera) of America North of
   Mexico.
AU Scholtens, Brian G. (scholtensb@cofc.edu) 
   Solis, M. Alma
SO ZooKeys
VL 535
PS 1-136
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB An annotated check list of Pyraloidea of North America north of Mexico
   is presented, including 861 Crambidae and 681 Pyralidae with 1542 total
   species. It includes all new species described, tropical species with
   new records in the United States, and species introduced from Europe and
   Asia since 1983. The Notes section provides the seminal citations, data
   and/or commentary to all changes since 1983 for easy and future
   reference. In addition, this list proposes seven new generic
   combinations, the transfer of a phycitine species, Salebria nigricans
   (Hulst), to Epipaschiinae and its syn. n. with Pococera fuscolotella
   (Ragonot), and three new records for the United States. Purposefully, no
   new taxa are described here, but we found a gradual increase of 10% in
   the number of species described since 1983. Finally, we also include a
   list of thirteen species not included or removed from the MONA list.
   Many higher-level changes have occurred since 1983 and the
   classification is updated to reflect research over the last 30 years,
   including exclusion of Thyrididae and Hyblaeidae from the superfamily
   and recognition of Crambidae and Pyralidae as separate families. The
   list includes multiple changes to subfamilies based on morphology such
   as the synonymization of the Dichogamini with the Glaphyriinae, but also
   incorporating recent molecular phylogenetic results such as the
   synonymization of the Evergestinae with the Glaphyriinae.
C1 Scholtens, Brian G.; Coll Charleston, Dept Biol, Charleston, SC, 29424,
   USA, USA.
EM scholtensb@cofc.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   North America

DT Article
TI Eriophyoid mites (Acari, Eriophyoidea) associated with tea plants, with
   descriptions of a new genus and two new species.
AU Han, Xiao
   Zuo, Yun
   Xue, Xiao-Feng
   Hong, Xiao-Yue (xyhong@njau.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 534
PS 1-16
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and two new species of mites in the family Eriophyidae,
   Theaphyes rapaneae gen. n. and sp. n. which is found on the type host
   Rapanea neriifolia (Sieb. et Zucc.) Mez (Myrsinaceae) and Paracaphyllisa
   theacea sp. n., are described and illustrated. They are vagrants on the
   tea plant Camellia sinensis (L.) Kuntze and no apparent symptoms were
   detected. A key to the eriophyoid mites including thirteen species
   associated with tea plants all over the world is provided.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of cyclopoid (Crustacea, Copepoda, Cyclopinidae)
   from a coastal system in the Gulf of Mexico.
AU Suarez-Morales, Eduardo (esuarez@ecosur.mx) 
   Almeyda-Artigas, Roberto Javier
SO ZooKeys
VL 534
PS 17-34
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new, monotypic genus of the interstitial marine cyclopoid copepod
   family Cyclopinidae G.O. Sars, 1913 is described from male and female
   specimens collected at Laguna de Terminos, a large coastal lagoon system
   in the southern Gulf of Mexico. Mexiclopina campechana gen. et sp. n.
   cannot be adequately placed in any extant genus within the family. It
   differs from other cyclopinid genera in having a unique combination of
   characters including: 1) absence of modified brush-like seta on the
   mandibular exopod; 2) maxillule exopod with stout setal elements and
   brush-like setae absent; 3) basis of mandible with one seta; 4) presence
   of a modified seta on endopod of fourth leg; 5) fifth leg exopod
   unsegmented, armed with three elements in the female and five in the
   male; 6) intercoxal sclerite of first swimming leg with two medial
   spiniform processes on distal margin. The new genus is monotypic and
   appears to be most closely related to Cyclopina Claus, 1863 and
   Heptnerina Ivanenko & Defaye, 2004; the new species was compared with
   species of Cyclopina and it resembles C. americana Herbst, 1982 and C.
   caissara Lotufo, 1994. This is the second record of a species of
   Cyclopinidae in Mexico and the first in the Gulf of Mexico; the number
   of cyclopinid species recorded from the Americas is now 13.
C1 Suarez-Morales, Eduardo; ECOSUR, Unidad Chetumal, AP 424, Chetumal,
   Quintana Roo, 77014, Mexico, Mexico.
EM esuarez@ecosur.mx
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Mexiclopina campechana [Gulf of Mexico / Mexico / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Cyclopoida
OR Mexiclopina (Cyclopoida): [Gen nov, Of family Cyclopinidae, Type species
   Mexiclopina campechana, p. 19]. 
   Mexiclopina campechana (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 20].

OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Paratullbergia Womersley in China: the description of a new species and
   a key to the genus (Collembola, Tullbergiidae).
AU Bu, Yun (buy@sstm.org.cn) 
   Gao, Yan
SO ZooKeys
VL 534
PS 55-60
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Paratullbergia Womersley, 1930 is recorded for the first time
   from China. Paratullbergia changfengensis sp. n. from Shanghai is
   described and illustrated. It is characterized by the presence of 1+1
   pseudocelli on thoracic segment I, with two pairs of pseudocelli on each
   of thoracic segments II and III, presence of seta px on abdominal
   segment IV, seta a2 and p4 on abdominal segment V as microsetae, and
   less differentiated sensory seta p3 on abdominal segment V. Both sexes
   present. The new species can be easily distinguished from its congeners
   by the presence of pseudocelli on thoracic segment I. An updated key to
   the world species of the genus Paratullbergia is provided.
C1 Bu, Yun; Shanghai Sci & Technol Museum, Shanghai Nat Hist Museum,
   Shanghai, 200041, China, China.
EM buy@sstm.org.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Paratullbergia [China /  / New record]. 
   Paratullbergia changfengensis [Shanghai /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Collembola

   key, p. 59; New record].

TI Review of the genus Hieromantis Meyrick from China, with descriptions of
   three new species (Lepidoptera, Stathmopodidae).
AU Guan, Wei
   Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 534
PS 85-102
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Six species of the genus Hieromantis occurring in China are reviewed.
   Hieromantis rectangula sp. n., H. arcuata sp. n. and H. puerensis sp. n.
   are described as new, and H. phaeodora Meyrick, 1929 is newly recorded
   in China. Photographs of adults and illustrations of genitalia are
   provided, along with an identification key and a distribution map.

DT Article
TI Description of a new genus and three new species of Otothyrinae
   (Siluriformes, Loricariidae).
AU Roxo, Fabio F. (roxoff@hotmail.com.br) 
   Silva, Gabriel S.C.
   Ochoa, Luz E.
   Oliveira, Claudio
SO ZooKeys
VL 534
PS 103-134
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The genus Hisonotus was resurrected as a member of the tribe Otothyrini
   (actually subfamily Otothyrinae). However, phylogenetic studies based on
   morphological and molecular data showed that Hisonotus is not
   monophyletic and independent lineages can be identified, such as the
   group composed of the species H. insperatus, H. luteofrenatus, H.
   oliveirai, H. paresi and H. piracanjuba, a lineage unrelated to that
   containing the type species of the genus Hisonotus (H. notatus). Herein,
   based in molecular and morphological data, a new genus is described to
   accommodate the lineage mentioned above, into which are also added three
   new species. This new genus can be distinguished from other genera of
   Otothyrinae by the following combination of characters: (1) a pair of
   rostral plates at the tip of the snout; (2) two large pre-nasal plates
   just posterior to the rostral plates; (3) a supra-opercular plate that
   receives the laterosensory canal from the compound pterotic before the
   preopercle; (4) a well developed membrane at anal opening in females;
   and (5) a V-shaped spinelet. A key to species of Curculionichthys is
   provided.
C1 Roxo, Fabio F.; Univ Estadual Paulista, Dept Morfol, Rubiao Jr S-N,
   Botucatu, SP, BR-18618970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM roxoff@hotmail.com.br
RI Ochoa, Luz/AAF-1148-2019; Oliveira, Claudio/D-7713-2012
OI Oliveira, Claudio/0000-0002-7010-8880; Ochoa, Luz/0000-0003-4205-8510

TI A new Antaeotricha species from Florida sandhills and scrub
   (Lepidoptera, Depressariidae, Stenomatinae).
AU Hayden, James E. (James.Hayden@FreshFromFlorida.com) 
   Dickel, Terhune S.
SO ZooKeys
VL 533
PS 133-150
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Antaeotricha floridella sp. n. is described and diagnosed from the
   closely similar A. albulella (Walker). The species is distributed in
   xeric sandhill and scrub habitats in peninsular Florida, USA, and larvae
   feed on Quercus species. Keys are given for pale-winged Stenomatinae and
   similar Gelechioidea based on external characters and genitalia.

DT Article
TI A new species of jumping spider Neonella Gertsch, with notes on the
   genus and male identification key (Araneae, Salticidae).
AU Rubio, Gonzalo D. (grubio@conicet.gov.ar) 
   Arganaraz, Carina I.
   Gleiser, Raquel M.
SO ZooKeys
VL 532
PS 1-14
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The American genus Neonella Gertsch, 1936 consists of very small jumping
   spiders whose biology is not well known. The genus currently includes
   eleven valid species, of which eight are known from both sexes and two
   are only known from one sex. This paper describes and illustrates a new
   species Neonella acostae sp. n., demonstrates male palpal variation in
   Neonella montana Galiano, 1988, and provides some information on the
   ecology of three sympatric species. New records of N. montana and N.
   minuta Galiano, 1965 are reported. Because the previously described
   species of Neonella were well illustrated and diagnosed, a dichotomous
   key to males is given along with genital illustrations of both sexes for
   all known species.
C1 Rubio, Gonzalo D.; Univ Nacl Misiones, Inst Biol Subtrop, Puerto Iguazu,
   Misiones, Argentina, Argentina.
EM grubio@conicet.gov.ar
RI Arganaraz, Carina I/M-7559-2017
OI Rubio, Gonzalo Daniel/0000-0002-4223-2980
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Key; Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Neonella acostae [Argentina /  / New species]. 
   Neonella minuta; Neonella montana [Ecology /  / New record] [Argentina /
   Cordoba / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Neonella - Gertsch 1936 (Araneae): [Key to species, Males, p. 12]. 
   Neonella acostae (Araneae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 4]. 
   Neonella minuta (Araneae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Review of the genus Urgleptes Dillon (1956) of Hispaniola (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Acanthocinini): descriptions of five new species and one
   new synonymy.
AU Ravin, Ian S.
   Lingafelter, Steven W. (steve.lingafelter@ars.usda.gov) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 532
PS 55-85
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The genus Urgleptes Dillon (1956) is reviewed for Hispaniola. Five new
   species of Urgleptes from the Dominican Republic are described herein:
   U. charynae Ravin & Lingafelter, sp. n. (La Vega province), U.
   conjunctus Ravin & Lingafelter, sp. n. (Peravia Prov.), U. curtipennis
   Ravin & Lingafelter, sp. n. (Independencia Prov.), U. marionae Ravin &
   Lingafelter, sp. n. (Monsenor Nouel Prov.), and U. obliteratus Ravin &
   Lingafelter, sp. n. (Pedernales Prov.). Two additional, previously
   described species are newly recorded for Hispaniola: U. puertoricensis
   Gilmour and U. sandersoni Gilmour. It is established that U. haitiensis
   Gilmour is a new synonym of U. sandersoni. Thus there are seven species
   of Urgleptes recorded for Hispaniola. For all species photographs,
   illustrations, full descriptions, distribution maps, and a dichotomous
   key are included for their identification.
C1 Lingafelter, Steven W.; Natl Museum Nat Hist, USDA, Washington, DC,
   20013, USA, USA.
EM steve.lingafelter@ars.usda.gov

SN 1313-2970

   Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

   taxonomic review]. 
   Urgleptes charynae; Urgleptes conjunctus; Urgleptes curtipennis;
   Urgleptes marionae; Urgleptes obliteratus [Dominican Republic /  / New
   species]. 
   Urgleptes puertoricensis [Dominican Republic /  / New record].

   Cerambycidae

   Republic, P. 83]. 
   Urgleptes charynae (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 68]. 
   Urgleptes conjunctus (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P.
   71]. 
   Urgleptes curtipennis (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P.
   74]. 
   Urgleptes marionae (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 76].

TI A second species of Cheleion from Johor, Malaysia (Coleoptera,
   Scarabaeidae, Aphodiinae, Stereomerini).
AU Kral, David (kral@natur.cuni.cz) 
   Hajek, Jiri
SO ZooKeys
VL 532
PS 87-97
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB A new species of the genus Cheleion Vardal & Forshage, 2010, Cheleion
   jendeki sp. n., from Johor, Malaysia is described, illustrated and
   compared with the type species of the genus, C. malayanum Vardal &
   Forshage, 2010. Photographs of the two species are presented. The
   adaptation to inquilinous lifestyle of Cheleion is compared with those
   in other beetle groups and briefly discussed.

TI Two new species of the genus Nephrotoma (Diptera, Tipuloidea, Tipulidae)
   from China with a key to species from Mainland China.
AU Men, Qiu-Lei (menqiulei888@126.com) 
   Xue, Guo-Xi
   Yang, Hai
SO ZooKeys
VL 532
PS 117-136
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Nephrotoma liankangensis sp. n. and N. pseudoliankangensis sp. n. are
   described from males and females collected from Henan and Yunnan
   provinces, China. Morphological descriptions and illustrations for the
   new species are provided. A key to known species from mainland China is
   provided. Some internal reproductive structures, including male semen
   pump, female vaginal apodeme and spermatheca, are described and
   compared. The possible usefulness of these internal reproductive
   structures for separating related species is analyzed. The type
   specimens are deposited in the animal specimen room, School of Life
   Sciences, Anqing Normal University, Anhui Province, China.
C1 Men, Qiu-Lei; Anqing Normal Univ, Prov Key Lab Biodivers Study & Ecol
   Conservat Sou, Anqing, Anhui, 246011, China, China.

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Nephrotoma pseudoliankangensis [Yunnan /  / New species].

TI Additions to the knowledge of the land snails of Sabah (Malaysia,
   Borneo), including 48 new species.
AU Vermeulen, Jaap J.
   Liew, Thor-Seng
   Schilthuizen, Menno (menno.schilthuizen@naturalis.nl) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 531
PS 1-139
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB We present reviews of the Sabah (Malaysia, on the island of Borneo)
   species of the following problematical genera of land snails (Mollusca,
   Gastropoda): Acmella and Anaglyphula (Caenogastropoda: Assimineidae);
   Ditropopsis (Caenogastropoda: Cyclophoridae); Microcystina (Pulmonata:
   Ariophantidae); Philalanka and Thysanota (Pulmonata: Endodontidae);
   Kaliella, Rahula, (Pulmonata: Euconulidae); Trochomorpha and Geotrochus
   (Pulmonata: Trochomorphidae). Next to this, we describe new species in
   previously revised genera, such as Diplommatina (Diplommatinidae);
   Georissa (Hydrocenidae); as well as some new species of genera not
   revised previously, such as Japonia (Cyclophoridae); Durgella and Dyakia
   (Ariophantidae); Amphidromus, and Trachia (Camaenidae); Paralaoma
   (Punctidae); Curvella (Subulinidae). All descriptions are based on the
   morphology of the shells. We distinguish the following 48 new species:
   Acmella cyrtoglyphe, A. umbilicata, A. ovoidea, A. nana, A.
   subcancellata, A. striata, and Anaglyphula sauroderma (Assimineidae);
   Ditropopsis davisoni, D. trachychilus, D. constricta, D. tyloacron, D.
   cincta, and Japonia anceps (Cyclophoridae); Diplommatina bidentata and
   D. tylocheilos (Diplommatinidae); Georissa leucococca and G. nephrostoma
   (Hydrocenidae); Durgella densestriata, Dyakia chlorosoma, Microcystina
   microrhynchus, M. callifera, M. striatula, M. planiuscula, and M.
   physotrochus (Ariophantidae); Amphidromus psephos and Trachia
   serpentinitica (Camaenidae); Philalanka tambunanensis, P. obscura, P.
   anomphala, P. rugulosa, and P. malimgunung (Endodontidae); Kaliella
   eurytrochus, K. sublaxa, K. phacomorpha, K. punctata, K. microsoma,
   Rahula delopleura, (Euconulidae); Paralaoma angusta (Punctidae);
   Curvella hadrotes (Subulinidae); Trochomorpha trachus, T. haptoderma, T.
   thelecoryphe, Geotrochus oedobasis, G. spilokeiria, G. scolops, G.
   kitteli, G. subscalaris, and G. meristorhachis (Trochomorphidae).

PM 26692797
DT Article
TI Two new Truncatelloidea species from Melissotrypa Cave in Greece
   (Caenogastropoda).
AU Falniowski, Andrzej (andrzej.falniowski@uj.edu.pl) 
   Sarbu, Serban
SO ZooKeys
VL 530
PS 1-14
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In the small lake located in the cave Melissotrypa in Thessalia, Greece,
   truncatelloidean gastropods representing two species were found, new to
   science. One of them, represented by two specimens only, has been
   described based on the shell characters only; with its cytochrome
   oxidase sequence it has been assigned to the genus Iglica, and to the
   family Moitessieriidae, Iglica hellenica sp. n. For the other species,
   represented by 30 collected specimens, the shell, protoconch, radula,
   head, penis and female reproductive organs have been described; all the
   morphological characters and cytochrome oxidase sequences have confirmed
   its assignment to the genus Daphniola (Hydrobiidae: Sadlerianinae),
   Daphniola magdalenae Falniowski, sp. n.
C1 Falniowski, Andrzej; Jagiellonian Univ, Inst Zool, Gronostajowa 9,
   Krakow, PL-30387, Poland, Poland.
EM andrzej.falniowski@uj.edu.pl
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Daphniola magdalenae; Iglica hellenica [Greece /  / New species].

ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda, Rissoidea
OR Daphniola magdalenae - Andrzej Falniowski 2015 (Rissoidea): [Sp nov,
   Greece, P. 6]. 
   Iglica hellenica (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 3].

DT Article
TI A new species of Jesogammarus from the Iki Island, Japan (Crustacea,
   Amphipoda, Anisogammaridae).
AU Tomikawa, Ko (tomikawa@hiroshima-u.ac.jp) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 530
PS 15-36
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of anisogammarid amphipod, Jesogammarus (Jesogammarus)
   ikiensis sp. n., is described from freshwaters in the Iki Island,
   Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan, based on results of morphological and
   molecular analyses. The new species is distinguished from all members of
   the genus by the combination of small number of setae on dorsal margins
   of pleonites 1-3, short and small number of setae on posterior margins
   of peduncular articles of antennae, mandibular article 1 without setae,
   well developed posterior lobes of accessory lobes of coxal gills on
   gnathopod 2 and pereopods 3-5, and pectinate setae on palmar margin of
   female gnathopod 2. A key to all the species of Jesogammarus is
   provided.
C1 Tomikawa, Ko; Hiroshima Univ, Grad Sch Educ, Higashihiroshima, 7398524,
   Japan, Japan.
EM tomikawa@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
RI Tomikawa, Ko/W-3062-2017

SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Jesogammarus (Jesogammarus) ikiensis [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Jesogammarus - Bousfield 1979 (Amphipoda): [Key to species, P. 33].

   21].

PM 26692799
DT Article
TI Review of New Caledonian species of Oxyethira Eaton, with description of
   17 new species, and new records for Hydroptila Dalman and Hellyethira
   Neboiss (Trichoptera, Hydroptilidae).
AU Wells, Alice (alice.wells@environment.gov.au) 
   Johanson, Kjell Arne
SO ZooKeys
VL 530
PS 37-90
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB New Caledonian representation of the cosmopolitan genus Oxyethira Eaton
   is reviewed, with the description of new species bringing to 26 the
   total for the genus on the island. The species are referred to three
   subgenera: Trichoglene Neboiss (11 species), Pacificotrichia Kelley (13
   species) and Dampfitrichia Ulmer (one species) and one species is
   unplaced to subgenus. A key is provided to Oxyethira species of New
   Caledonia. In addition, new records are given for two otherwise
   Australian species, Hydroptila losida Mosely and Hellyethira malleoforma
   Wells. Points marked on a series of small maps of New Caledonia indicate
   the site or sites at which the species were collected. This final paper
   in a series of generic revisions brings the hydroptilid fauna of the
   island of New Caledonia to 60 species, distributed in six genera.
C1 Wells, Alice; Australian Biol Resources Study, Box 787, Canberra, ACT,
   2601, Australia, Australia.
EM alice.wells@environment.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

DT Article
TI Ashea megacephala Kim & Ahn (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Aleocharinae), a
   new gyrophaenine genus and species from Peru.
AU Kim, Yoon-Ho
   Ahn, Kee-Jeong (kjahn@cnu.ac.kr) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 530
PS 91-99
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ashea megacephala, a new Peruvian genus and species is described. The
   specimens were collected on mushrooms and mushroom-associated trees.
   This genus can be readily distinguished from the other genera of the
   subtribe Gyrophaenina by the large head and the three indistinctly
   articulated labial palpomeres. A key to the known genera of Gyrophaenina
   is provided. A habitus photograph and illustrations of diagnostic
   characters are also presented.
C1 Ahn, Kee-Jeong; Chungnam Natl Univ, Dept Biol, Taejon, 34134, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM kjahn@cnu.ac.kr
OI Ahn, Kee-Jeong/0000-0003-4880-0931

SN 1313-2970

   Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Pycnogonids associated with the giant lion's-paw scallop Nodipecten
   subnodosus (Sowerby) in Ojo de Liebre Bay, Guerrero Negro, Baja
   California Sur, Mexico.
AU de Leon-Espinosa, Angel
   de Leon-Gonzalez, Jesus A. (jesus.deleongn@uanl.edu.mx) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 530
PS 129-149
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB Five species of epibenthic pycnogonids collected on the giant lion's-paw
   scallop Nodipecten subnodosus are recorded. A new species of Eurycyde,
   E. bamberi, is described. Of the 19 species known in this genus; the new
   species is closest to E. hispida Kroyer, 1844 but differs from it in the
   absence of plumose spines and the shapes of the lateral process, first
   coxa, and ocular tubercle. The new species represents the third member
   of Eurycyde from the eastern Pacific in addition to E. spinosa Hilton,
   1916 and E. clitellaria Stock, 1955. Besides E. bamberi, the following
   species were collected: Nymphopsis duodorsospinosa Hilton, 1942c;
   Callipallene californiensis (Hall, 1913); Nymphon lituus Child, 1979;
   and Pycnogonum rickettsi Schmitt, 1934. Pycnogonum rickettsi is recorded
   for first time from Mexican waters, as is Nymphon lituus from the
   western coast of Baja California Peninsula. Each of these four species
   are re-described and re-illustrated in order to fill in existing gaps in
   the literature of the region.
C1 de Leon-Gonzalez, Jesus A.; Univ Autonoma Nuevo Leon, Fac Ciencias Biol,
   Ap Postal 5 F, San Nicolas De Los Garza, Nuevo Leon, 66451, Mexico,
   Mexico.
EM jesus.deleongn@uanl.edu.mx
OI de Leon-Gonzalez, Jesus Angel/0000-0003-2314-240X
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description;
   Associations; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   record; systematics] [North Pacific / Mexico, Baja California Sur /
   Arthropod associates; distribution]. 
   Nymphon lituus [North Pacific / Mexico, Baja California / New record]. 
   Pycnogonida [Associations / Nodipecten subnodosus (Mollusca) / New
   record; systematics] [North Pacific / Mexico, Baja California Sur /
   Molluscan associates; distribution]. 
   Pycnogonum rickettsi [North Pacific / Mexico / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Pycnogonida, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Pteriomorphia,
   Ostreoida, Pectinoidea

   Callipallene californiensis - (Hall 1913) (Pycnogonida): [Redescription,
   P. 139].

DT Article
TI Phylogenetic revision of Minyomerus Horn, 1876 sec. Jansen & Franz, 2015
   (Coleoptera, Curculionidae) using taxonomic concept annotations and
   alignments.
AU Jansen, M. Andrew (entojansen@gmail.com) 
   Franz, Nico M.
SO ZooKeys
VL 528
PS 1-133
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB This contribution adopts the taxonomic concept annotation and alignment
   approach. Accordingly, and where indicated, previous and newly inferred
   meanings of taxonomic names are individuated according to one specific
   source. Articulations among these concepts and pairwise, logically
   consistent alignments of original and revisionary classifications are
   also provided, in addition to conventional nomenclatural provenance
   information. A phylogenetic revision of the broad-nosed weevil genera
   Minyomerus Horn, 1876 sec. O'Brien & Wibmer (1982), and Piscatopus
   Sleeper, 1960 sec. O'Brien & Wibmer (1982) (Curculionidae (non-focal):
   Entiminae (non-focal): Tanymecini (non-focal)) is presented. Prior to
   this study, Minyomerus sec. O'Brien & Wibmer (1982) contained seven
   species, whereas the monotypic Piscatopus sec. O'Brien & Wibmer (1982)
   was comprised solely of P. griseus Sleeper, 1960 sec. O'Brien & Wibmer
   (1982). We thoroughly redescribe these recognized species-level entities
   and furthermore describe ten species as new to science: M. bulbifrons
   sec. Jansen & Franz (2015) (henceforth: (JF2015)), sp. n., M. aeriballux
   (JF2015), sp. n., M. cracens (JF2015), sp. n., M. gravivultus (JF2015),
   sp. n., M. imberbus (JF2015), sp. n., M. reburrus (JF2015), sp. n., M.
   politus (JF2015), sp. n., M. puticulatus (JF2015), sp. n., M.
   rutellirostris (JF2015), sp. n., and M. trisetosus (JF2015), sp. n. A
   cladistic analysis using 46 morphological characters of 22 terminal taxa
   (5/17 outgroup/ingroup) yielded a single most-parsimonious cladogram (L
   = 82, CI = 65, RI = 82). The analysis strongly supports the monophyly of
   Minyomerus (JF2015) with eight unreversed synapomorphies, and places P.
   griseus sec. O'Brien & Wibmer (1982) within the genus as sister to M.
   rutellirostris (JF2015). Accordingly, Piscatopus sec. Sleeper (1960),
   syn. n. is changed to junior synonymy of Minyomerus (JF2015), and its
   sole member P. griseus sec. Sleeper (1960) is moved to Minyomerus
   (JF2015) as M. griseus (JF2015), comb. n. In addition, the formerly
   designated type M. innocuus Horn, 1876 sec. Pierce (1913), syn. n. is
   changed to junior synonymy of M. microps (Say, 1831) (JF2015) which has
   priority. The genus is widespread throughout western North America,
   ranging from Canada to Mexico and Baja California. Apparent patterns of
   interspecific diversity of exterior and genitalic morphology, varying
   host plant ranges, overlapping and widely extending species
   distributions, suggest an early origin for Minyomerus (JF2015), with a
   diversification that likely followed the development of North American
   desert biomes. Three species in the genus - i.e., M. languidus Horn,
   1876 (JF2015), M. microps (JF2015), and M. trisetosus (JF2015) - are
   putatively considered parthenogenetic.
C1 Jansen, M. Andrew; Arizona State Univ, Sch Life Sci, POB 874501, Tempe,
   AZ, 85287, USA, USA.
EM entojansen@gmail.com
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Parasitology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Reproduction; Evolution; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA

TI A revision of the genus Doryodes Guenee, 1857, with descriptions of six
   new species (Lepidoptera, Erebidae, Catocalinae, Euclidiini).
AU Lafontaine, J. Donald (Don.Lafontaine@agr.gc.ca) 
   Sullivan, J. Bolling
SO ZooKeys

PS 3-30
PD 2015

LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Doryodes Guenee is revised to include ten species including
   six species described as new (D. desoto Lafontaine & Sullivan; D.
   okaloosa Sullivan & Lafontaine; D. fusselli Sullivan & Lafontaine; D.
   reineckei Sullivan & Lafontaine; D. broui Lafontaine & Sullivan; and D.
   latistriga Sullivan & Lafontaine). A key to species, descriptions, and
   illustrations of adults and genitalia are included.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Heteranassa Smith, 1899 (Lepidoptera, Erebidae,
   Omopterini).
AU Homziak, Nicholas (nhomziak@ufl.edu) 
   Hopkins, Heidi
   Miller, Kelly B.
SO ZooKeys
VL 527
PS 31-49
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Heteranassa Smith (Erebidae, Omopterini), native to the southwestern
   United States and Mexico, includes two recognized species, namely H.
   mima (Harvey) and H. fraterna Smith. These are separated mainly by
   subtle differences in wing color and pattern, leading to speculation
   about the validity of the described species. This study examines
   variation in external and internal morphology across the geographic
   range of the genus, aiming to clarify species limits, describe
   morphology, and provide a comprehensive assessment of variation within
   the genus. Results indicate that H. fraterna syn. n., is a junior
   synonym of H. mima.

   FL, 32611, USA, USA.

TI A new species of Ogdoconta Butler (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Condicinae,
   Condicini) from southeastern Arizona, USA.
AU Crabo, Lars G. (lcrabo@nwrads.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 527
PS 51-56
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Ogdoconta Butler (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Condicinae,
   Condicini) is described from the Patagonia Mountains, Santa Cruz County,
   Arizona, USA. Ogdoconta margareta sp. n., is related closely to
   Ogdoconta tacna (Barnes) from Texas. Modifications are proposed to a
   recently published key to the Ogdoconta species north of Mexico to allow
   identification of the new species.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Aseptis McDunnough (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae,
   Noctuinae, Xylenini) with a description of two new genera, Paraseptis
   and Viridiseptis.
AU Mustelin, Tomas (tmustelin@burnham.org) 
   Crabo, Lars G.
SO ZooKeys
VL 527
PS 57-102
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Aseptis McDunnough (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Noctuinae,
   Xylenini, Xylenina) is revised to include 15 species based on
   morphological and molecular data. Several new synonymies are introduced.
   In addition, two genera are described because of significant
   morphological differences from Aseptis: Paraseptis gen. n., and
   Viridiseptis gen. n., resulting in the new combinations Paraseptis
   adnixa (Grote), comb. n., and Viridiseptis marina (Grote), comb. n.
   Although this work is primarily based on morphological data, DNA
   sequence data for the 658-base pair "barcode" segment of the
   mitochondrial gene for subunit 1 of cytochrome c oxidase was used as a
   secondary support for taxonomic changes within Aseptis and for the two
   new genera. Our work should provide clarity and stability in a
   previously difficult genus.
C1 Mustelin, Tomas; San Diego Nat Hist Museum, San Diego, CA, 92101, USA,
   USA.
EM tmustelin@burnham.org
OI Mustelin, Tomas/0000-0001-5912-8840

   Synonymy; Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Key

   Noctuoidea, Noctuidae

TI Revision of the Lacinipolia vicina (Grote) complex (Noctuidae,
   Noctuinae, Eriopygini).
AU Schmidt, B. Christian (Chris.Schmidt@inspection.gc.ca) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 527
PS 103-126
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Lacinipolia vicina (Grote) species complex, previously consisting of
   L. vicina, L. teligera (Morrison), L. pensilis (Grote), and L. subalba
   Mustelin is revised to six species: L. vicina (eastern USA), L. teligera
   (southern Great Plains), L. pensilis (Pacific Northwest and northern
   Rocky Mountains), L. acutipennis (Grote), stat. rev. (= L. subalba syn.
   n.) (western North America), L. sareta (Smith), stat. rev. (Canada and
   western USA) and L. dimocki, sp. n. (California and Pacific Northwest).
   Lectotypes are designated for L. vicina, L. teligera and L. pensilis.

DT Article
TI Additions and corrections to the check list of the Noctuoidea (Insecta,
   Lepidoptera) of North America north of Mexico III.
AU Lafontaine, J. Donald (Don.Lafontaine@agr.gc.ca) 
   Schmidt, B. Christian
SO ZooKeys
VL 527
PS 127-147
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A total of 124 additions and corrections are listed and discussed for
   the check list of the Noctuoidea of North America north of Mexico
   published in 2010. Twenty-eight species are added to the list, 16
   through new species descriptions, eight as a result of taxonomic splits,
   and four based on newly recorded species. Forty-eight species are
   deleted from the list, 41 through synonymy, and seven that were based on
   misidentifications. Twelve changes are corrections in the spelling of
   names, or changes in parentheses on dates of publication. Twenty-seven
   are changes in taxonomy of names where no species are added or deleted;
   eight changes involve the renumbering of existing species for better
   taxonomic arrangement. Within the text 2 stat. n., 10 stat. rev., 27
   syn. n., 5 syn. rev., and 1 comb. n. are proposed for the first time.
C1 Lafontaine, J. Donald; Agr & Agri Food Canada, Canadian Natl Collect
   Insects Arachnids & Nematod, KW Neatby Bldg,960 Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON,
   K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201002226
DT Article
TI Natural Enemies of Tuta absoluta (Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae) in Oued Righ
   Region, An Arid Area of Algeria.
AU Dehliz, A.
   Guenaoui, Y.
SO Academic Journal of Entomology
VL 8
IS 2
PS 72-79
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In this study, information about natural enemies of the invasive tomato
   leafminer moth Tuta absoluta is presented from the southern part of
   Algeria. First, the most important natural enemies associated with this
   pest were listed. Furthermore, the life-history traits of the most
   representative larval parasitoid Necremnus artynes (Walker) at
   laboratory conditions was presented. Among predators of T. absoluta,
   three species were recorded: Macrolophus pygmaeus (Rambur) and
   Nesidiocoris tenuis (Reuter) belonging to Miridae family and Orius
   (Heteroptera: Antocoridae). The generalist bug N. tenuis is the most
   abundant because of its resistance to high temperatures. Parasitoids of
   T. absoluta are mainly: Hemiptarsenus zilahisebessi, Bracon hebetor,
   Neochrysocharis formosa and Stenomesius sp. This last one was not
   announced in the North of Algeria. The species identified as N. artynes
   was the most often found in the samples but its performances do not make
   it possible to use as biological agent of control under the conditions
   of the arid areas. At temperature conditions of 17[degree]C as minimum
   and 23[degree]C as maximum, 16 L: 08 D photoperiod and 60 [plus or
   minus] 10 % RH, the parasitoid N. artynes showed a parasitism rate of
   20,38 [plus or minus] 01,19 %, a female fecundity of 03,33 [plus or
   minus] 01,87 eggs/female, a duration of life cycle (egg-adult) of 17,96
   [plus or minus] 02,53 days, an adult longevity of 05,45 [plus or minus]
   01,79 days and 04,27 [plus or minus] 01,08 days for females and males
   respectively.
C1 Dehliz, A.; Univ Abdelhamid Ibn Badis, Mostaganem, Algeria, Algeria.
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Entomology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Reproductive
   Biology; Developmental Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology

   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Ecology; Population
   dynamics; Population structure; Predators; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Bracon hebetor; Hemiptarsenus zilahisebessi; Neochrysocharis formosa;
   Stenomesius [Lepidopteran hosts / Tuta absoluta / ] [Algeria / Oued Righ
   / ].

   absoluta (Lepidoptera) / ] [Algeria / Oued Righ / ].

   /  / ] [Longevity /  / ] [Lepidopteran hosts / Tuta absoluta / ]

   [Desert habitat /  / ] [Algeria / Oued Righ / ] [ /  / ] [ /  / ].

DT Article
TI Peripodisma ceraunii (Orthoptera, Acrididae, Melanoplinae: Podismini), a
   new species of the genus Peripodisma from southern Albania.
AU Lemonnier-Darcennont, Michele (lemonniergeem@free.fr) 
   Darcemont, Christian
SO Articulata
VL 30
IS 1
PS 53-62
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Peripodisma was previously known only from a single species,
   P. tymphii Willemse, 1972, found in the Epirus region in Greece,
   especially in the Pindos mountains. In summer 2014, we discovered a new
   population of Peripodisma, morphologically differentiated from P.
   tymphii, in the Gjirokaster sector of Albania. This led US to describe
   the new taxon, P. Ilofizii (LEMONNIER-DARCEMONT & CHRISTIAN DARCEMONT
   2015). In autumn 2014 we found a third population in the Vlore District
   in southern Albania on Mount Qores. The individuals from this area are
   morphologically different from P. tymphii and more close to P. Ilofizii.
   Nevertheless they show some differences in the colouration of the hind
   tibia, the shape of the supra-anal-plate and the male penis. These
   morphological differences and the relative geographic isolation of Mount
   Qores from the Gjirokaster massive further east, allow separating
   Peripodisma ceraunii n. sp. from the other two species of this genus.
C1 Lemonnier-Darcennont, Michele; GEEM, 240 Chemin Vignaou, Callian,
   F-83440, France, France.
EM lemonniergeem@free.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0171-4090
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Peripodisma ceraunii [Albania /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Peripodisma ceraunii (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Albania, P. 54].

TI A new species of the genus Mimacronia Vives, 2009 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae).
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 15
IS 1
PS 1-8
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Mimacronia Vives, 2009 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae), which is endemic to the Philippine archipelago, is
   described and illustrated. New taxonomic changes are proposed:
   Mimacronia viridimaculata (Breuning, 1947) stat. n. and comb. n.. (from
   Acronia alboplagiata var. viridimaculata Breuning, 1947) = Mimacronia
   novemmaculata Hudepohl, 1995 syn. n. An updated catalogue of the genus
   Mimacronia is given.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201001367
DT Article
TI SYSTEMATIC REVISION OF THE NORTH AMERICAN SYNTROPINE VAEJOVID SCORPIONS
   WITH A SUBACULEAR TUBERCLE, KONETONTLI GONZALEZ-SANTILLAN AND PRENDINI,
   2013.
AU Gonzalez-Santillan, Edmundo
   Prendini, Lorenzo
SO Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
VL 397
PS 1-78
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB The Mexican vaejovid scorpion genus Konentontli Gonzalez-Santillan and
   Prendini, 2013, was created to accommodate five species united, among
   other characters, by a subaculear tubercle on the telson. Species of
   Konetontli are among the smallest vaejovid scorpions. Their very small
   size, cryptic coloration, and apparently seasonal surface activity may
   explain their rarity in collections and it is likely that more
   undescribed species await discovery. In the present contribution, we
   describe four new species (Konetontli ignes, sp. nov.; Konetontli
   ilitchi, sp. nov.; Konetontli juxtlahuaca, sp. nov.; Konetontli migrus,
   sp. nov.) and revalidate Konetontli zihuatanejensis (Baldazo-Monsivaiz,
   2003), comb. nov., previously synonymized with Konetontli acapulco
   (Armas and Martin-Frias, 2001), raising to 10 the number of species in
   the genus; redescribe previously described species, including the first
   description of the female of Konetontli nayarit (Armas and Martin-Frias,
   2001); and present new records, comprehensive distribution maps, and a
   key to the identification of the species.
C1 Gonzalez-Santillan, Edmundo; CUNY, New York, NY, 10021, USA, USA.
RI Santillan, Edmundo Gonzalez/B-7648-2014
OI Santillan, Edmundo Gonzalez/0000-0003-1340-068X
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0003-0090

   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key;
   General morphology; Ecology; Distribution within habitat; Abiotic
   factors; Physical factors; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Konetontli [General morphology /  / new record; taxonomic revision]
   [Vertical distribution /  / ] [Altitude /  / ] [Mexico /  /
   distribution]. 
   Konetontli ignes; Konetontli ilitchi; Konetontli juxtlahuaca; Konetontli
   migrus [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Konetontli - Gonzalez-Santillan & Prendini 2013 (Scorpiones): [Revision,
   P. 3; Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P. 35; Key to species,
   P. 14; New record]. 
   Konetontli acapulco - (Armas & Martin-Frias 2001) (Scorpiones):
   [Redescription, P. 15; Removal from synonymy, Vaejovis zihuatanejensis
   Baldazo-Monsivaiz 2003, p. 71].

   P. 29].

   designated, P. 71; Removal from synonymy, With Konetontli acapulco
   (Armas & Martin-Frias 2001), p. 71; Referred to, Konetontli, p. 71].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201003458
DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF WOOD-BORER BEETLES (COLEOPTERA: PTINIDAE) FROM
   CENTRAL ASIA.
AU Toskina, I.N.
SO Byulleten' Moskovskogo Obshchestva Ispytatelei Prirody Otdel
   Biologicheskii
VL 120
IS 1
PS 35-39
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species are described from Uzbekistan: Lasioderma bukhariensis
   sp. nov. (subfam. Xyletininae) and Ptilinus zebekiensis sp. nov.
   (subfam. Ptilininae). L. bukhariensis is rufous, pubescence suberect,
   light yellow. Antennae: 3rd segment as long as the 2nd one; 4-7th
   segments with straight apical and lateral margins, longitudinal; eyes
   separated by 1.9 eye diameters. Pronotum 1.6 times as wide as long,
   without posterior angles, pubescence parted to two sides; surface with
   dual punctation. Elytra 1.6 times as long as wide, surface with fine
   wrinkles and punctures. Anterior rims of metasternum are very slightly
   approximated in the middle. Fore tibiae not dilated towards apex.
   Aedeagus: internal penial sac with two spines at the apex, sinuous row
   of 6 spines and 2 small spines in its middle. Length 2.85 mm. L.
   bukhariensis differs from L. logvinovskii Toskina, 1998, L.
   pectecapilhtm Toskina, 2011, and L. redtenbacheri (Bach, 1852) having
   rufous colour, pubescence parted to two sides on pronotum, and not
   dilated fore tibiae, by antennomeres which are strongly transverse in
   the first species, with convex lateral margins in the second species,
   and with long 3rd segment (1.5-1.7 times as long as the 2nd segment) in
   the third species. Also elytra are shorter in L. pectecapilhan (ratio
   between length and width is 1.4 in the latter and 1.6 in the new
   species); pronotum with posterior angles in L. redtenbacheri (pronotum
   without posterior angles in new species). Internal penial sac is
   provided with different armaments (6 spines of various sizes in L.
   pectecapillum, and 3 large spines and 2 rows of small spines in L.
   redtenbacheri). Ptilinus uzbekiensis is black, antennae and tarsi
   yellow. Eyes separated by about 2 eye diameters. Antennae: 3rd segment
   triangular, with notch, ramus of 7th segment is 4 times as long as the
   segment itself. Pronotum 1.1 times as wide as long, without shining
   places and coarse large teeth. Elytra 2 times as long as wide, almost
   without "costae"; bands of punctures are broad. Fore tibiae with rather
   long apical tooth. Aedeagus: paramerae with long notch. Length 4.0 mm.
   The new species differs from other Ptilinus in Central Asia with short
   rami of antennomeres (P. fuscus Geoffroy, 1785, P. iranicus Toskina,
   1995, P. panfilovi Toskina, 1995) by the following characters. All the
   three species have short tooth on fore tibia apex. 3rd antennomere with
   digitate process and 6-7th segments with rami which are 5 times as long
   as their segment in P. fitscus and P. panfilovi. On the contrary, P.
   iranicus has shorter rami: 3 times as long as the 7th antennomere
   itself; pronotum with deep middle line and transverse bulge. The end of
   aedeagus of P. firscus is shown for comparison. Oligomerus retowskii
   Schilsky, 1898 is found for the first time in the Central Asia
   (Tadzhikistan). It was established that Peritheca gyrosa Logvinovskij,
   1978 and P. phototropus Logvinovskij, 1978 belong to different genera,
   and the latter should be removed from the genus Peritheca to another
   genus.
SC Zoology
SN 0027-1403
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Lasioderma bukhariensis; Ptilinus uzbekiensis [Uzbekistan /  / New
   species]. 
   Oligomerus retowskii [Tajikistan /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Bostrichoidea,
   Anobiidae
OR Lasioderma bukhariensis (Anobiidae): [Sp nov, Uzbekistan, P. 35]. 
   Oligomerus retowskii (Anobiidae): [New record]. 
   Peritheca phototropus - Logvinovskij 1978 (Anobiidae): [Taxonomic
   position, P. 38]. 
   Ptilinus uzbekiensis (Anobiidae): [Sp nov, Uzbekistan, P. 36]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201003458
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15201002614
DT Article
TI First record of the assassin bug genus Coilopus Elkins, 1969 (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Reduviidae) from Colombia.
AU Forero, Dimitri (forero-i@javeriana.edu.co) 
   Giraldo-Echeverry, Nicolas
SO Check List
VL 11
IS 3
PS 1634
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The assassin bug genus Coilopus Elkins, 1969 is recorded for the first
   time from Colombia. Coilopus vellus Elkins, 1969 is a wasp mimic that
   was previously recorded from Costa Rica, French Guiana, and Brazil. The
   Colombian specimens fill the distributional gap between the known
   Central and South American records. In addition, based on collected
   wasps from the same place as Coilopus, Mischocyttarus sp. (Vespidae:
   Polistinae) is proposed as the hymenopteran model of this mimetic
   harpactorine.
C1 Forero, Dimitri; Pontificia Univ Javeriana, Dept Biol, Carrera 7 43-82,
   Bogota, Colombia, Colombia.
EM forero-i@javeriana.edu.co
RI Forero, Dimitri/P-4860-2016
OI Forero, Dimitri/0000-0002-6358-757X
SC Zoology
SN 1809-127X

DE Coilopus; Coilopus vellus [Colombia /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs

   Reduvoidea, Reduviidae
OR Coilopus (Reduviidae): [New record]. 
   Coilopus vellus (Reduviidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI [Cobosidea name. nov (= Suareziella Cobos, 1964, nec Mamet, 1954), new
   genus of the Eucnemidae family and new genus for the fauna of French
   Guiana (Coleoptera, Eucnemidae, Macraulacinae, Macraulacini).]
FT Cobosidea nom. nov. (= Suareziella Cobos, 1964, nec Mamet, 1954),
   nouveau genre de la famille des Eucnemidae et genre nouveau pour la
   faune de Guyane (Coleoptera, Eucnemidae, Macraulacinae, Macraulacini).
AU Chassain, Jacques (jacques.chassain@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Coleopteriste
VL 18
IS 1
PS 8-9
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper relates to gen. Suareziella Cobos 1964 (nec Suareziella
   Mamet, 1954), a brasilian false clickbeetle genus (Eucnemidae) with
   peculiar facies from Matto Grosso, of which only one female exemplar
   named bispinosa Cobos, 1964 was known up to now. This species has been
   newly collected with light trap in French Guiana. It is new as well as
   corresponding genus for French guianese fauna. According to Muona, 1987,
   Suareziella Cobos, 1964 is the junior homonym of Suareziella Mamet,
   1954. Accordingly, it is replaced here by the taxon Cobosidea, nom. nov.
C1 Chassain, Jacques; 12 Allee Cormier, Combs La Ville, F-77380, France,
   France.
EM jacques.chassain@wanadoo.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0751-0284
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Available name; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Elateroidea,
   Eucnemidae
OR Cobosidea (Eucnemidae): [Nom nov, For Suareziella Cobos 1964, p. 8; New
   record]. 
   Cobosidea mihi (Eucnemidae): [New record]. 
   Suareziella - Cobos 1964 (Eucnemidae): [Preoccupied name replaced by,

TI [Second contribution to the knowledge of afro-tropical Melolonthinae
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeoidea, Melolonthidae).]
FT Deuxieme contribution a la connaissance des Melolonthinae afro-tropicaux
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeoidea, Melolonthidae).
AU Lacroix, Marc (hannetons@free.fr) 
SO Coleopteriste
VL 18
IS 1
PS 41-45
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The examination of an important lot of recently collected afrotropical
   Melolonthinae and belonging to the I.R.Sc.N.B. Bruxelles allowed the
   description of a new species, as well as to widen the distribution of a
   number of species. The new species is Neopegylis jolyi n. gen. n. sp.
   from Gabon. Four species widen their distribution to new countries:
   Pegylis murphyi Lacroix (Zambia), Pegylis neumanni Kolbe (Zambia),
   Afrolepis congoensis (Moser) (Gabon) and Afrolepis ivorensis Decelle
   (Togo).

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006196
DT Article
TI A new early brachyuran (Crustacea, Decapoda) from the Middle Jurassic of
   northwest France, epibionts and ecological considerations.
AU Robin, Ninon (ninon.robin@edu.mnhn.fr) 
   van Bakel, Barry W.M.
   d'Hondt, Jean-Loup
   Charbonnier, Sylvain
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 84
IS 3
PS 179-191
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The earliest known crabs are of Early and Middle Jurassic age; in
   general, they are rare. Here we describe a new species of homolodromioid
   from the late Bathonian of Sarthe (France), based on a single dorsal
   carapace, Tanidromites raboeufi n. sp. This specimen has mostly
   well-preserved cuticle, and shows two episkeletozoans (bryozoan
   colonies) on its dorsal side, which is unique amongst early brachyurans
   (Early and Middle Jurassic). These bryozoans are identified as juvenile
   colonies of the morphogenus Berenicea (sheet-like tubuluporines),
   typical encrusters of hard substrates. Their presence directly on the
   carapace crab shows that they were closely cohabitating with this early
   brachyuran in its palaeoenvironment. One of these colonies appears to
   have attached to the internal carapace surface, indicative of
   post-mortem settlement and growth. Colony sizes suggest a growth phase
   of at least several months on the sea floor, implying a certain
   resistance to decomposition of the crab carapace. This is of note in the
   light of extant homolodromioids which are known to have extremely
   fragile carapaces. This association demonstrates that post-mortem
   associations may yield palaeoecological insights into both substrate and
   colonising organisms.
C1 Robin, Ninon; Univ Paris 06, CNRS, 8 Rue Buffon, Paris, F-75005, France,
   France.
EM ninon.robin@edu.mnhn.fr
RI ROBIN, Ninon/H-3120-2017; Charbonnier, Sylvain/AAU-9571-2020
OI ROBIN, Ninon/0000-0002-1756-3171; 
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1383-4517
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Ecology; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   associate species] [ / Tanidromites (Crustacea) / Epibiont; associate

   species] [ / North west / crustacean associates] [Jurassic /  / ] [ /
   Middle Jurassic / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201005357
DT Article
TI Controversies and consensus on the lionfish invasion in the Western
   Atlantic Ocean.
AU Carballo-Cardenas, Eira C.
SO Ecology and Society
VL 20
IS 3
PS 24
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 76
AB This study investigates how the lionfish (Pterois sp.) invasion of the
   Western Atlantic Ocean has been socially constructed by natural
   scientists, the media, and stakeholders associated with various marine
   protected areas in the Caribbean. By examining the use of data and
   metaphors by these actors, I identify where invasion discourses converge
   and diverge. Although consensus exists regarding the non-nativeness,
   introduction vector, and successful establishment of lionfish throughout
   the region, I also identify uncertainty surrounding lionfish impact and
   controversies regarding lionfish management and control. The dominant
   discourse frames lionfish as a threat and control efforts as a war to
   keep the enemy at bay, and promotes lionfish hunting and consumption by
   humans: the "ultimate predators." However, this view is challenged by a
   coalition that questions the safety, effectiveness, and morality of the
   practices promoted by the kill-and-eat lionfish coalition. A nascent
   discourse that frames lionfish as fulfilling the role of overexploited
   native species, primarily expressed in socioeconomic terms, is shifting
   lionfish impact perception from negative to positive among some
   stakeholder groups. Whereas the dominant discourse views humans as
   helping nature to regain balance through lionfish hunting, a minority
   coalition views lionfish as part of the ecosystem, where a new
   equilibrium will be reached. This study shows that scientific data and
   metaphors, amplified by the media, facilitated initial understanding of
   the lionfish phenomenon and are used to legitimize claims. In time,
   however, local knowledge and societal values have intermingled with
   scientific data, sometimes challenging scientific discourses, and
   contributing to a richer understanding of the invasion as a
   social-ecological phenomenon.
C1 Carballo-Cardenas, Eira C.; Univ Wageningen & Res Ctr, Environm Policy
   Grp, Wageningen, NL-6700 HB, Netherlands, Netherlands.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation
BD Animals and man; Conservation; Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of
   dispersal; Marine zones
DE Pterois [Disturbance by man /  / ] [Conservation measures /  / ]
   [Introduction / Invasive species / ] [Atlantic Ocean / West / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Scorpaeniformes, Scorpaenidae
OR Pterois (Scorpaenidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201005357
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15201003122

TI First Record of Venturia sp Parasitizing the Coconut Moth.
AU Oliveira Queiroz, Abel Felipe
   Ambrogi, Bianca Giuliano (abelfelipi@gmail.com) 
   Santos, Jucileide Lima
   Nascimento, Eduardo Silva
SO EntomoBrasilis
VL 8
IS 2
PS 165-167
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The coconut moth Atheloca subrufella Hulst (Lepidoptera: Phycitidae) is
   considered an important pest of coconut crops in Brazil, which is the
   fourth largest global coconut producer. Concerning the economic
   importance of this crop and aiming to increase the knowledge related to
   biological control, the present research aimed records the first
   occurrence of Venturia sp. (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) parasitizing A.
   subrufella caterpillars in the State of Sergipe, Brazil. Coconuts
   infested by A. subrufella caterpillars were collected in coconut
   plantation and kept in the Entomology Laboratory (Universidade Federal
   de Sergipe - UFS) until the emergence of A. subrufella adults or the
   parasitoids. The parasitoids obtained were identified as Venturia sp..

PT J
AN ZOOR15201003510
DT Article
TI Biodiversity across the Guadalupian-Lopingian Boundary: first results on
   the ostracod (Crustacea) fauna, Chaotian section (Sichuan Province,
   South China).
AU Zazzali, Sindbad (sindbad.zazzali@upmc.fr) 
   Crasquin, Sylvie
   Deconinck, Jean-Francois
   Feng, Qinglai
SO Geodiversitas
VL 37
IS 3
PS 283-313
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB The Middle Permian-Late Permian boundary (Guadalupian-Lopingian
   boundary, GLB) interval is characterised by important faunal assemblage
   changes. This extinction-turnover episode is considered by some authors
   to be the first step of the end-Permian biodiversity drop. The
   forty-five meters thickness of sediment encompassing the GLB in Chaotian
   section (Sichuan Province, South China) was sampled and processed for
   ostracod study. This study presents the first analysis of ostracod
   faunas in the GLB interval. A total of 154 species belonging to 29
   genera are identified. Three species are described as new: Bairdia
   chaotianensis Zazzali, n. sp., Microchedinella wujiapingensis Zazzali,
   n. sp., Microcheilinella pagodaensis Zazzali, n. sp. All the ostracods
   discovered in the section belong to shallow marine taxa. So these
   results are not consistent with previous interpretations (lagoonal
   environment or deep water setting) based on other evidences. Abundance
   and diversity present a rapid and noticeable decline in the Early
   Capitanian. Recovery is then recorded about three meters above the GLB.
   At specific level, a 93% extinction rate and a 96% turnover rate are
   recorded at the GLB. Moreover, Palaeocopida, straight dorsal border
   ostracods known to progressively disappear from the Late Permian to the
   basal Middle-Triassic, are here less abundant and diversified after the
   GLB. This could reflect the first step of their disappearance at the end
   of the Palaeozoic.
C1 Zazzali, Sindbad; Univ Paris 06, Univ Paris 04, T46-56,E5,Case 104,4 Pl
   Jussieu, Paris, F-75252, France, France.
EM sindbad.zazzali@upmc.fr
RI Crasquin, Sylvie/AAT-9631-2020
OI Crasquin, Sylvie/0000-0003-4358-3827
SC Zoology
SN 1280-9659
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Bairdia chaotianensis; Microcheilinella pagodaensis; Microcheilinella
   wujiapingensis [Sichuan /  / new species] [Permian /  / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Sichuan /  / stratigraphical distribution; systematics]
   [Permian / Guadalupian-Lopingian boundary / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Ostracoda (Crustacea): [Fossil]. 
   Bairdia chaotianensis (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Sichuan, Permian, P. 292;
   Fossil].
